titleStmt.title: Copres, a Village tesserarius of Pharbaithos, in the Arsinoite Nome

encodingDesc.ab: Converted from a Word document for Pylon.

docTitle.titlePart: Copres, a Village tesserarius of Pharbaithos, in the Arsinoite Nome

div.p:
#acknowledgement
I would like to thank Rodney Ast (Institute for Papyrology, Heidelberg University) for allowing me to publish this papyrus, Elke Fuchs (Institute for Papyrology, Heidelberg University) for providing photographs of it, and the editors and anonymous reviewers for their valuable comments and corrections on previous versions of the manuscript. All errors are my own. The dates are Common Era unless specified otherwise.

This paper deals with a papyrus from the Heidelberg Papyrussammlung under the inventory number G 263. Although very fragmentary, one can observe that it consists most probably of an account or tax register given the list of names. One of the most interesting aspects revolving around this document is the attestation of a compulsory village public service office called tesserarius held by a certain Copres.
For the village teserarii see Boak 1951; Lewis 1997: 47 and Berkes 2017: 65 and 203. The papyrus has been sold to the Heidelberg University by K. Reinhardt, the first Dragoman of the German Imperial General Consulate in Cairo, who purchased it in 1896 among various other antiquities.
See in detail Seider 1964: passim. Most recently about the history of the acquisition also in Deac 2024, §1. The provenance is unknown, but it was implied on the card accompanying the papyrus that the provenance might be the Arsinoite nome, based on what is believed to be the name of the village of Pharbaithos.
https://doi.org/10.11588/diglit.67024 accessed on October 3rd 2024 (link embedded in edition header). ʽInhalt: Liste; Steuer; Liste mit Namen von Steuerzahlern u. ihren Zahlungen. Militär: tessararius. Personennamen: Kopres. Herkunft: Arsinoites(?)ʼ. The verso is blank.

div.head: The fragmentary light brown papyrus bears a text placed on two columns. Col. I, on the left, preserves the end of some lines, while the intercolumnium is 1.5 cm. On col. II, one can trace 12 lines written in black ink. It can be implied that on col. II we are dealing with the beginning of the lines, but not the entire wording, as parts of some names and numbers of this column are missing on the right, the most conclusive in this regard being the last part of the name which begins in l. 8 but whose beginning was written on l. 7. The entire text is written along the fibers by one hand at least on col. II. The endings of the lines from col. I, located at the bottom side of the document, seem to have the strokes written a little thinner than the rest, perhaps by another hand.

Although the papyrus is fragmented, one can observe from col. II that the document lists mainly a series of names, which look like part of an account or list of a tax-register, or something related. At least the bottom half of col. II which starts roughly 2 cm beneath the text above, refers to individuals from the village of Pharbaithos. The upper half might refer to individuals from another settlement of the Arsinoite nome.

Given the presence of γράμματα next to λίτραι and perhaps ὀγκίαι in the lacuna in l. 6 of the second column, one can interpret the text as referring to either gold or silver measures. These were offered by or were requisitioned from individuals like Germanos, Pasis, Dioskoros, Horion and Philoxenos, residents of an unknown village; it's equaled weight is measured in pounds, ounces and grams of which we know the last measurement unit. The next section concerns the list of residents of Pharbaithos, individuals like Papeas, Sarapion, Copres, the village tesserarius, Aunion or Venerius who also accounted for goods measured in the same manner, whose total had to be mentioned at the end of the list of names.

Most of the names written in the document are rather frequently attested. The ones that occur more often are the Greek ones such as Ἡρακλῆς (TM Nam 4560) or Ἡρακλείδης (TM Nam 4550) or a version very similar, Αὐνίων – TM Nam 6688, Διόσκορος – TM Nam 2828, Ὡρίων – TM Nam 43787, Φιλόξενος – TM Nam 3267, Σαραπίων – TM Nam 5663, Κοπρῆς – TM Nam 3702, Κάστωρ - TM Nam 3574 or Καστορίων – TM Nam 19065.
Most of these names are included in the analysis published in a recent paper by Clarysse and Thompson 2025, which focuses on the Greek names of Egypt, relying heavily on statistical data extracted from the well-known databases, mainly LGPN (Lexicon of Greek Personal Names) and TM Names (Trismegistos People). Three are of Egyptian origin, namely Παως, derived from the Egyptian Pa-ḥr – TM Nam 743, Πᾶσις, derived from the Egyptian Pa-sy – TM Nam 760, and Ἀμαις – TM Nam 1926. Finally, at least one of the names is Latin, i.e. Germanos – TM Nam 6853, and perhaps also Ianuarius (?) – TM Nam 9608 and Venerius. The origin of the name Λάιος is unknown - TM Nam 22295.

Pharbaithos (TM Geo 1750) refers to a village in the Arsinoite nome, in the Herakleides district, somewhere near another village called Persea (TM Geo 1701), both of which are still not identified on the ground. Interestingly, this is only the second occurrence of this village name in documentary papyri which can be securely dated in the 4th century, the previous one being a list of payments of money, perhaps also a tax register or an account mentioning a list of villages discovered at Karanis (SB 22 15825).

As said above, one of the most interesting aspects revolves around Copres, the tesserarius of the village of Pharbaithos. He had been appointed in this village compulsory public service office called tesserarius, of which we hardly know anything, except, perhaps, that it is attested only in the fourth century, hence the dating. Moreover, the semi-cursive, rather skilled, practiced and upright handwriting points to the same period. What has been identified so far, based on the available papyrological sources, is that this office lasted for six months, individuals like Copres being appointed either at the beginning of the year (on 1 Thot) or on the 1 Phamenoth, and N. Lewis notes that ʽa confusing variety of duties is attested in the documentsʼ, regarding the tesserarius (Lewis 1997: 47). Earlier, A. E. R. Boak notes that ʽ(…) he [i.e. the tesserarius] was a civilian village official appointed primarily to supervise the collection of certain public imposts levied upon the villages, particularly perhaps the levies imposed to meet the needs of the military establishmentʽ (Boak 1951: 333). Apparently, as N. Lewis stated, literacy was not required for this office (Lewis 1997: 47), as the best known tesserarius, Aurelius Isidorus from Karanis, who held this position around 313 – early 314 AD, was himself illiterate, as is revealed by a number of documents from his archive (TM archID 34).

div.p: 1.-9. Except for Φ̣ιλοξ- in l. 9, only groups or traces of letters are visible, in the last three lines slightly effaced, to the same degree as the phi from Φαρβεθων (Col 2, l.7). The Φ̣ιλοξ- sequence might refer to the name Φ̣ιλόξ[ενος (TM Nam 3267) or one of its variants, perhaps indicating the same person as in Col. 2, l. 5.

1. above omicron and sigma from Germanos one can distinguish two descending strokes which must be part of the first name in this line. For the second name of the line, which is heavily effaced, one can observe a vertical stroke and parts of the diagonal strokes (especially the descending one) which stands for kappa; traces of the next letter are visible as well, namely a part of the left diagonal stroke of a letter that might be interpreted as a lambda. Thus, the name should be a form for instance of Ἡρακλῆς (TM Nam 4560) or Ἡρακλείδης (TM Nam 4550) but this aspect cannot be determined with certainty. A second interpretation which cannot be completely disregarded is that the line refers to Ἡρακ̣λ̣ε̣ί̣[δου μερίδος].

2. Παός instead of Παῶς appears with omicron instead of omega only once more, in the nominative, in a fiscal diary from Dionysias, in the Arsinoite nome (SB 26 16560.107). However, the name here should have been in genitive since it must have been a patronymic.

3. Ἀμαει represents the patronymic, of a name that is frequently attested in the Arsinoite nome, i.e. Ἀμαις (TM Nam 1926). Further, the line is quite effaced, which makes reading the second name difficult. Before the name the preposition διὰ can be read without alpha as the abbreviation stroke is visible after iota; here one can observe a diaeresis as, after the preposition, a personal name starting with iota follows, which can be read as Ἰανο̣υ̣[αρίου (TM Nam 9608).

6. the closest analogy is an unprovenanced document concerning silver tableware inventory dated to the 1st century, which on two occasions states after γίνονται the number of λίτραι, ὀγκίαι and γράμματα (BGU 3 781 col. I, l.9 and col. VI, l.5). The same succession of λίτραι, ὀγκίαι and γράμματα is to be found in an early 4th century assessment of gold and silver (P.Oxy. 46 3307. 26) in accounts of receipts and expenditure (P.Oxy. 16, 1918, esp. recto col. I, l. 15) from the Apion archive (TM Arch 15) and an account issued by the Antaiopolis office of finance (P.Cair. Masp. 1 67057. 19-22), part of the Dioskoros archive (TM Arch 72).

7. Φαρβέθων has to be understood in genitive plural and occurs under this form when reference is made to the name of the village in a register of a tax collector from Philadelphia (SB 20 14576. 516), while on two other instances in the same document the village name appears written as Φαρβαίθ(ων) (SB 20 14576. 540, 549); for this very common interchange – αι/ε – see Gignac 1976: 192-193.

8. before καὶ, the last part of a personal name in nominative appears, which would have started in the previous line. Here, perhaps as in the case of Ἀμαει discussed above, the final sigma has been also deliberately omitted. Such a name ending, of woman named […]απέας, in accusative, is to be found in a papyrus which cannot be classified with certainty, found at Ptolemais Euergetis, in the Arsinoite nome, dated March 15th 306 (BGU 2 606. 2-3: παρὰ Α[ὐρηλίου Σαραπίωνος μη(τρὸς)] | [ ̣ ̣]απέας). Alternatively, one should interpret it as a name which has parallels outside Egypt, at Panticapeum, in the Bosporan Kingdom, on an funerary monument dated to the 2nd – 3rd centuries which reads Παπέα(ς); the editor of CIRB, V. Struve, is unsure in whether the text refers to a male or female individual (CIRB 730,2 reads Παπέα; LGPN IV, 270, Παπέας. Less likely, a solution might be found on an inscribed block with panel from Dinek Serai, at the border of Lycaonia and Isauria, which reads as Δορμαπεα or, perhaps, Δορμαπενα. MAMA VIII, 129. 2: [Αὐρ.] Λόνγιλλα ἡ καὶ | [Κ]ύ̣ριλλα Αὐρ. Δορμαπε α | Θεοφιλιανῷ τῷ | καὶ Ἀρείονι ἰδίῳ ἀνδρὶ | 5μνήμης χάριν.; W. M. Calder proposes an alternative reading of the name Δορμαπενα given the fact that he notes that ʽbefore the final A of line 2, which is carved below E, the copy inserts N.ʼ; L. Zgusta agrees with this possibility, highlighting that Δορμαπεα is a masculine name in dative, thus the nominative Δορμαπεας (Zgusta 1964: 151, § 300-2); see also Laminger-Pascher 1992: 189, no. 303 and LGPN V.C, 129 (Δορμαπεας).
10. the large oblique stroke before Aunion looks like a checkmark and belongs to col. II.

11. If the fourth letter is a nu, than one should read a personal name, Οὐενέριος, attested for the first time in Egypt; outside Egypt this name is presumed from an epitaph discovered at Thessalonike, in Macedonia, dated to the middle 2nd century to the middle of the 3rd century (Adam-Belene and Sverkos 2001: 24-26, no. 5; AE 2001, 1773; BE 2002, 278; SEG 51, 895). The nominative would explain also the elongated horizontal stroke of the partially visible sigma that goes above the first three letters of the next word. Less likely, if the letter is to be interpreted as a tau, with its horizontal stroke now missing, then the reading should be οὐετερ[ανὸ]ς, instead of the more common οὐετρανὸς; this form – οὐετερανὸς – is encountered in the 4th century solely in a document concerning a sale of a house (P.Sakaon 59. 19) from the archive of Aurelius Sakaon (TM archID 206). The status of a veteran might refer to Aunion, son of Sarapion, read in the previous line. For a veteran to appear in this list is not surprising as a veteran community existed in the Arsinoite during the Principate (Alston 1995: esp. 39-51 with the critical remarks and further bibliographic references in Fischer-Bovet and Sänger 2019: 171; for an overview on the veterans from Egypt from the 1st to the 3rd century see latest Sänger 2010 and also Haensch 2012: 76 with references). In the archive of Flavius Abinnaeus (P.Abinnaeus), at that time prefectus of the ala quinta Praelectorum, from at Dionysias, in the Fayum, one can observe many veterans acting as petitioners addressing these petitions to the commander Abinnaeus (TM archID 1) as outlined by Fischer-Bovet and Sänger 2019: esp. 174-175. The patronymic can be read as the name Λάιος (TM Nam 22295).

12. there are two options in reading the last visible letter. If one interprets it as an omicron then one reads the patronymic Ḳάστορο̣[ς of a person whose name was written in the preceding line. Another possibility would be, for example, that this letter is an abraded iota and thus the reading goes in nominative - Ḳαστορί̣[ων - or as a patronymic - Ḳαστορί̣[ωνος.

listBibl.bibl: Adam-Belene, P. and Sverkos, E. (2001) “Επιτάφιες στήλες από τη Θεσσαλονίκη,” in Η. Σβέρκος (εκδ.), Α΄ Πανελλήνιο Συνέδριο Επιγραφικής. Στη μνήμη Δημήτριου Κανατσούλη, Θεσσαλονίκη 22-23 Οκτωβρίου 1999. Θεσσαλονίκη: 13-34.
Alston, R. (1995) Soldier and Society in Roman Egypt. A Social History. London & New-York.
Berkes, L. (2017) Dorfverwaltung und Dorfgemeinschaft in Ägypten von Diokletian zu den Abbasiden.

Boak, A. E. R. (1951) “Tesserarii and Quadrarii as Village Officials in Egypt of the Fourth Century,” in Paul R. Coleman-Norton (eds.), Studies in Roman Economic and Social History in Honor of Allan Chester Johnson, Princeton: 322–335.
CIRB = V. Struve (ed.) (1965) Corpus inscriptionum regni Bosporani. Moscow.
Clarysse, W. and Thompson, D. (2025) “New Rulers, New Names. Greek Names of Egypt,” in: A. Almásy-Martin, Y. Broux (eds.), Oxford Studies in Ancient Documents. Oxford: 48-120.
Deac, D. (2024) “Macedonias and Other Toponyms from the Panopolite Nome,” Pylon 6.
Fischer‐Bovet, C. and Sänger, P. (2019) “Security and Border Policy: Army and Police,” in K. Vandorpe (ed.), A Companion to Greco-Roman and Late Antique Egypt. Hoboken: 163–178.
Gignac, F. T. (1976) A Grammar of the Greek Papyri of the Roman and Byzantine Periods. Milano.
Haensch, R. (2012) “The Roman Army in Egypt,” in: C. Riggs (ed.), The Oxford Handbook of Roman Egypt. Oxford: 68–82.
Laminger-Pascher, G. (1992) Die Kaiserzeitlichen Inschriften Lykaoniens, Faszikel I: Der Süden, Tituli Asiae Minoris – Ergänzungsbände 15. Wien.
Lewis, N. (1997) The Compulsory Public Services of Roman Egypt. Papyrologica Florentina XXVIII. 2nd Edition. Florence.
LGPN V.C = Balzat, J.-S., Catling, R. W. V., Chiricat, É. and Corsten, T. (eds.) (2018) A Lexicon of Greek Personal Names. Volume V.C: Inland Asia Minor. Oxford.
MAMA VIII = Calder, W. M., and Cormack J. M. R., (eds.) (1962), Monumenta Asiae Minoris Antiqua vol. 8. Monuments from Lycaonia, the Pisido-Phrygian Borderland, Aphrodisias, Manchester.

Sänger, P. (2010) “Römische Veteranen in Ägypten (1.–3. Jh. n. Chr.): Ihre Siedlungsräume und sozio-ökonomische Situation,” in P. Herz, P. Schmid, O. Stoll (eds.), Zwischen Region und Reich. Das Gebiet der oberen Donau im Imperium Romanum. Berlin: 121–133.
Seider, R. (1964) “Aus der Arbeit der Universitätsinstitute. Die Universitäts-Papyrussammlung,” Heidelberger Jahrbücher 8: 142–203.

div.p: […] son of Herakl[…] sive Herakleides division […] Germanos, son of Paos […] Pasis, son of Amaius, through Ianuar[ius?… ], Dioskoros and Horion […] Philoxenos, son of Disokoros […]. […] total: [x] pounds, [x ounces], 11 grams […] (The village of) Pharbaithos […] […P?]apea(s) and Sarapion […] Copres, tesserarius […] Aunion, son of Sarapion […] Venerius, son of Laios […] (son of) Kastor/Kastorion […].
